Component: Layout - Page Header

Introduction

A Header and subnav component will be the first thing the user sees when they load up one of our pages. Maintaining a consistent UI across all pages will allow them to more easily navigate our site and prevent any potential issues with unease or awkwardness if they were going from page-to-page experiencing differing UIs.

NOTE: this component is considered an "extra" and are therefore not included in the base installation of Particles. This means that you have to explicitly include it in your Sass files.

  
    @import "[../]node_modules/@tesla/particles/scss/_particles/extras/tsla-page_header";

Standalone Page Header

Many content-heavy pages (About, Blog, Support articles, etc) simply need a way for their users to navigate around to different pages within the section. By adding a navigation like seen here, you can achieve this.

Hero Title

  1. Link 1
  2. Link 2
  3. Link 3
▲ 
<section class="tsla-page_header">
  <div class="tsla-page_header--content">
    <div class="container">
      <h1 class="tsla-page_header--title">Hero Title</h1>
      <nav class="tsla-page_header--nav tsla-sidescroll-menu" data-tsla_showsidescroll_arrow="true">
        <ol class="tsla-nav--list_items">
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 1" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 1</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item tsla-nav--item_selected">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 2" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 2</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 3" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 3</a>
          </li>
        </ol>
        <i class="tsla-sidescroll-arrow tsla-icon-angle_right"></i>
      </nav>
    </div>
  </div>
</section>

Header Image Component

The basic / default structure is two <source>s: 1 for each of the default breakpoints. Within each <source> element, you'll see 2 asset paths: 1 for non-retina, and another for retina. For more on the <picture> element, see below the example. A version of this markup is currently in use (as a video element instead of a picture element) on the Model 3 page.

For each of the listed <source>s you provide, you will also list image assets matching the pixel densities you support. By default, we support 2 breakpoints, and 2 pixel densities, but you can provide as many as you would like.

▲ 
<section class="tsla-page_header">
  <picture class="tsla-page_header--hero">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/320&text=FPO, //placehold.it/640&text=FPO 2x" media="(max-width: 640px)">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000&text=FPO 2x" media="(min-width: 640px)">
    <img class="tsla-page_header--fallback" src="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO" srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000&text=FPO 2x" alt="Hero Component">
  </picture>
</section>

Note on the <picture> element
a <picture> element is a wrapper for some <source>s and a fallback <img> asset. But what you gain from this is the ability to specify a range of image sizes for the browser to choose from, based on the following criteria:

  • Pixel density (1x, 2x, 3x, etc), and
  • Viewport size ((media="(max-width: 640px)"), (media="(min-width: 640px)", etc).

Providing this data to the browser allows it to download and render the image that is most suited for the context it finds itself. We provide the assets, and let the browser to the work of rendering the right asset. This means the browser will not download a 1000x1000 retina image if the correct size it needs is to render the asset is 500x500 non-retina image. Yay for smart browsers.

Available Options

  • Hero with Title and Subnav
  • Hero with Title Only
  • Hero with Sub-nav Only
  • Other Options
  • Integrating with the Side Scrolling Menu

There are several other options available to you with this hero component. Some of them much more common than others, but for the sake of completeness, all are documented.

Hero with Title and Subnav

The most common usage will be a header Images with a title and subnav. This type of setup is currently in use on all of our top-level marketing pages (Energy, Solar Roof, Model S, Model X, etc).

Your code should have the following:

  1. The default setup
  2. The tsla-page_header--content wrapper element (usually a div). This should be placed directly after the <picture> element
    • A tsla-page_header--title element (usually an h1). This should be placed inside the tsla-page_header--content wrapper element.
    • A tsla-page_header--nav element (usually a nav). This should be placed inside the tsla-page_header--content wrapper element.

Hero Title

  1. Link 1
  2. Link 2
  3. Link 3
▲ 
<section class="tsla-page_header">
  <picture class="tsla-page_header--hero">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/320&text=FPO, //placehold.it/640&text=FPO 2x" media="(max-width: 640px)">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000&text=FPO 2x" media="(min-width: 640px)">
    <img class="tsla-page_header--fallback" src="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO" srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000&text=FPO 2x" alt="Hero Component">
  </picture>
  <div class="tsla-page_header--content">
    <div class="container">
      <h1 class="tsla-page_header--title">Hero Title</h1>
      <nav class="tsla-page_header--nav">
        <ol class="tsla-nav--list_items">
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 1" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 1</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item tsla-nav--item_selected">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 2" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 2</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 3" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 3</a>
          </li>
        </ol>
      </nav>
    </div>
  </div>
</section>

Hero with Title Only

You may want to insert a header Images, but only want a title to be overlaid on top of the hero. This pattern can work well if you're on a standalone page with little-to-no related pages.

Your code should have the following:

  1. The default setup
  2. The tsla-page_header--content wrapper element (usually a div). This should be placed directly after the <picture> element
    • A tsla-page_header--title element (usually an h1). This should be placed inside the tsla-page_header--content wrapper element.

Hero Title

▲ 
<section class="tsla-page_header">
  <picture class="tsla-page_header--hero">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/320&text=FPO, //placehold.it/640&text=FPO 2x" media="(max-width: 640px)">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000&text=FPO 2x" media="(min-width: 640px)">
    <img class="tsla-page_header--fallback" src="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO" srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000&text=FPO 2x" alt="Hero Component">
  </picture>
  <div class="tsla-page_header--content">
    <div class="container">
      <h1 class="tsla-page_header--title">Hero Title</h1>
    </div>
  </div>
</section>

Hero with Sub-nav Only

The least common option among all of these is a Hero with a sub nav only.

Your code should have the following:

  1. The default setup
  2. The tsla-page_header--content wrapper element (usually a div). This should be placed directly after the <picture> element
    • A tsla-page_header--nav element (usually a nav). This should be placed inside the tsla-page_header--content wrapper element.
  1. Link 1
  2. Link 2
  3. Link 3
▲ 
<section class="tsla-page_header">
  <picture class="tsla-page_header--hero">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/320&text=FPO, //placehold.it/640&text=FPO 2x" media="(max-width: 640px)">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000&text=FPO 2x" media="(min-width: 640px)">
    <img class="tsla-page_header--fallback" src="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO" srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000&text=FPO 2x" alt="Hero Component">
  </picture>
  <div class="tsla-page_header--content">
    <div class="container">
      <nav class="tsla-page_header--nav">
        <ol class="tsla-nav--list_items">
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 1" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 1</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item tsla-nav--item_selected">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 2" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 2</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 3" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 3</a>
          </li>
        </ol>
      </nav>
    </div>
  </div>
</section>

Other Options

By default, the text color will be dark, but maybe you are putting this on top of a header Images that is dark as well. The solve for this would be to add a class to the wrapper to use the alternate color scheme.

Hero Title

  1. Link 1
  2. Link 2
  3. Link 3
▲ 
<section class="tsla-page_header">
  <picture class="tsla-page_header--hero">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/320/333333/dddddd&text=FPO, //placehold.it/640/333333/dddddd&text=FPO 2x" media="(max-width: 640px)">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500/333333/dddddd&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000/333333/dddddd&text=FPO 2x" media="(min-width: 640px)">
    <img class="tsla-page_header--fallback" src="//placehold.it/1440x500/333333/dddddd&text=FPO" srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500/333333/dddddd&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000/333333/dddddd&text=FPO 2x" alt="Hero Component">
  </picture>
  <div class="tsla-page_header--content tsla-page_header--alternate">
    <div class="container">
      <h1 class="tsla-page_header--title">Hero Title</h1>
      <nav class="tsla-page_header--nav">
        <ol class="tsla-nav--list_items">
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 1" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 1</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item tsla-nav--item_selected">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 2" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 2</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 3" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 3</a>
          </li>
        </ol>
      </nav>
    </div>
  </div>
</section>

Integrating with the Side Scrolling Menu

Maybe you want to integrate with the side scrolling menu when viewed on mobile?

There are 3 changes you would need to make to the DOM to accomodate for this change:

  1. Add the class tsla-sidescroll-menu to <nav class="tsla-page_header--nav">
  2. Add the data attribute data-tsla_showsidescroll_arrow="true"> to <nav class="tsla-page_header--nav">
  3. Add the arrow icon (if desired on mobile): <i class="tsla-sidescroll-arrow tsla-icon-angle_right"></i>. This goes directly after the closing </ol> of <ol class="tsla-nav--list_items">

Everything else should "just work".

Hero Title

  1. Link 1
  2. Link 2
  3. Link 3
  4. Link 4
  5. Link 5
  6. Link 6
  7. Link 7
  8. Link 8
  9. Link 9

  11. Link 11
▲ 
<section class="tsla-page_header tsla-page_header--alternate">
  <picture class="tsla-page_header--hero">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/320/333333/dddddd&text=FPO, //placehold.it/640/333333/dddddd&text=FPO 2x" media="(max-width: 640px)">
    <source srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500/333333/dddddd&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000/333333/dddddd&text=FPO 2x" media="(min-width: 640px)">
    <img class="tsla-page_header--fallback" src="//placehold.it/1440x500/333333/dddddd&text=FPO" srcset="//placehold.it/1440x500/333333/dddddd&text=FPO, //placehold.it/2880x1000/333333/dddddd&text=FPO 2x" alt="Hero Component">
  </picture>
  <div class="tsla-page_header--content">
    <div class="container">
      <h1 class="tsla-page_header--title">Hero Title</h1>
      <nav class="tsla-page_header--nav tsla-sidescroll-menu" data-tsla_showsidescroll_arrow="true">
        <ol class="tsla-nav--list_items">
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 1" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 1</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item tsla-nav--item_selected">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 2" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 2</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 3" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 3</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 4" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 4</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 5" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 5</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 6" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 6</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 7" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 7</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 8" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 8</a>
          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 9" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 9</a>

          </li>
          <li class="tsla-nav--list_item">
            <a href="#" title="Nav link 11" class="tsla-nav--list_link">Link 11</a>
          </li>

        <i class="tsla-sidescroll-arrow tsla-icon-angle_right"></i>
      </nav>
    </div>
  </div>
</section>
